Context:
Program Name: Electromechanical Engineering Technology - Power and Control
Code: T182
Credential: Ontario College Advanced Diploma
Duration: 3 years (6 semesters)
Starting Months: January, September
Domestic Tuition: $5,980.00 *
International Tuition: $18,307.00 **
Location: Casa Loma Campus
Program Overview: Gain expertise in advanced power and control systems. Developed in collaboration with Toronto Hydro. Combines theoretical and practical experience.
Graduation: Ready to meet demands of industrial environments and advanced manufacturing industries. Expertise in installing, operating, maintaining, and troubleshooting high-tech automated equipment.
First two years: Experience with power and control systems, including electric motors, controls.

* Domestic tuition is for Canadian students.
** International tuition is for students studying from outside Canada.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Electromechanical Engineering Technology - Power and Control Program T182 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The text describes a three-year college program focused on power and control systems. In the first two years, students will study various aspects of power and control systems, including electric motors, controls, PLCs, generators, transformers, electrical CAD, and electrical safety code. Advanced courses in electrical installations, power transmission and distribution, power quality, electrical protection and control, project management, automation systems, and control applications are offered in the third year.

Students will complete two mandatory co-op semesters. The first co-op experience takes place between semesters 4 and 5, and the second co-op experience takes place between semesters 5 and 6.

Graduates of this program may find employment in various industries such as utilities, power generation and distribution, robotics and automation, computer industry, manufacturing industry, and renewable energy. The careers will primarily involve technological functions related to power and control systems, energy, robotics and automation, manufacturing, processing, and computer industries.

The following is a list of courses offered in the first two semesters:

Semester 1:
- EMNG 1001: Circuit Analysis
- MENG 1044: Introduction to Mechanical Engineering Design
- MENG 1045: Machining Fundamentals and Metrology
- MENG 1088: Occupational Health and Safety
- GSSC 1027: Personal Finance
- MATH 1160: Mathematics for Engineering Technology 1
- COMM 2000: Communicating Across Contexts

Semester 2:
- ELCL 1047: Residential Prints and Electrical Safety Code 1
- EMNG 1013: Electronic Devices
- EMNG 1015: Motors and Controls
- EMNG 1020: Computers and Microprocessors
- EMNG 1021: CAD Electrical Circuits
- MATH 1171: Mathematics for Engineering Technology 2
- GNED: General Education Elective

There is no specific information about any key entities or emails mentioned in the text.

Additionally, students may be required to take COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) before progressing to COMM 2000. The graduate is expected to demonstrate the ability to fabricate and build electrical, electronic and mechanical components and assemblies in accordance with operating standards, job requirements and specifications, analyze, interpret and produce electrical, electronic and mechanical drawings and other related technical documents and graphics necessary for electromechanical design in compliance with industry standards, and select and use a variety of troubleshooting techniques and equipment to assess, modify, maintain and repair electromechanical systems.

Context:
The text describes a program that focuses on assessing, modifying, maintaining and repairing electromechanical circuits, equipment, processes, systems and subsystems. This involves the modification, maintenance and repair of electrical, electronic and mechanical components and systems to optimize production and ensure they function according to specifications. The program covers design and analysis of mechanical components, processes and systems, as well as the design and analysis of industrial motor controls and data acquisition devices and systems, digital circuits, passive AC and DC circuits, active circuits and microprocessor-based systems.

Industrial automation is also a part of the program, with an emphasis on analyzing, programming, installing, integrating, troubleshooting and diagnosing automated systems, including robotic systems. The program includes establishing and maintaining inventory, records and documentation systems and selecting and purchasing electromechanical equipment, components and systems that fulfill job requirements.

Quality control and quality assurance programs and procedures are also part of the curriculum, along with working in compliance with industry standards and regulations. Personal and professional development is encouraged through ongoing strategies to enhance work performance and remain current in the field.

The text also mentions courses related to hydraulic and fluid power systems, project management, electrical cabling requirements, system grounding and bonding requirements, designing and commissioning electrical power systems, selecting and recommending power and control equipment, and applying systems analysis tools to minimize waste in power and control systems.

Tuition costs are listed as $5,980 for domestic students and $18,307 for international students, with additional costs not specified in the text.

* Domestic Tuition: $5,980.00
* International Tuition: $18,307.00
* Focus Areas: electromechanical circuits, equipment, processes, systems and subsystems; electrical, electronic and mechanical components and systems; industrial motor controls and data acquisition devices and systems; digital circuits, passive AC and DC circuits, active circuits and microprocessor-based systems; hydraulic and fluid power systems; project management; electrical cabling requirements; system grounding and bonding requirements; electrical power systems; power and control equipment, systems and components; systems analysis tools.

Context:
The text provides information about the estimated tuition fees for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2023 and Fall 2024 at George Brown College. The tuition fees are subject to change and do not include books, which students must purchase separately. Students are also responsible for purchasing CSA standard safety shoes and prescription safety glasses if needed.

The program is approved for OSAP funding for applicants who meet eligibility criteria. Applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent and grades 12 English (C or U) and either grade 11 Math (M or U) or grade 12 (C or U). Mature students without an OSSD may take the Admissions Assessment for English and Math or upgrade to achieve the required credits. International students should refer to specific admission requirements on the college website.

Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students should use the George Brown College Online Application System.

Contact information for the School of Mechanical Engineering Technologies is not provided in the text.

KEY INFORMATION:
- Programs starting in Fall 2023 and Fall 2024 tuition fees: $18,307.00 (estimated total of tuition, materials, student service and ancillary fees for first two semesters)
- Tuition fees subject to change
- Fees do not include books
- Students responsible for purchasing CSA standard safety shoes and prescription safety glasses if needed
- OSAP funding eligible for applicants who meet eligibility criteria
- Applicants need Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, grade 12 English (C or U), and either grade 11 Math (M or U) or grade 12 (C or U). Mature students may take Admissions Assessment for English and Math or upgrade to achieve required credits
- International students apply through the George Brown College Online Application System
- No contact information provided for School of Mechanical Engineering Technologies in text.
